text: The word 'neurodiversity' was coined in the 90s, but the community surrounding that word is in many ways even newer. People with diagnoses coming together online and sharing their lived experience has created new discourses that deserve respectful engagement.
tokenized_text: the word ' neurodiversity ' was coined in the 9 0 s , but the community surrounding that word is in many ways even newer . people with diagnoses coming together online and sharing their lived experience has created new discourses that deserve respectful engagement .

text: There's also an argument you can have about how far any of these labels pick out distinct things. Maybe "neurodiversity" is just a bigger, more inclusive spectrum that includes autism, ADHD and other stuff too. Or maybe not; I'm gonna leave that debate here.

text: Neurodiversity is the idea that it's normal and acceptable for people to have brains that function differently from one another. Rather than thinking there is something wrong or problematic when some people don't operate similarly to others, neurodiversity embraces differences.

text:
Or, neurodiverity anathema to them.

Anyway, part of the point is that we all really, really need to take a cue from the disability and neurodiversity movements and learn to stop seeing ANY disorders as “something wrong or broken with a person”, regardless of the origin of them.

text:
For those asking:

* Yes, I have a dark sense of humour
* Yes, I love twisted song lyrics
* Yes, I've had a lot of life changes in the past few months

text:
@Nickkadysh I propose a more simple test.  For gender, "race," ethnicity, LGBTQ, #neurodiversity issues, etc...

THE CHAUNCEY GARDNER TEST:
1) Reverse the genders, complexions, or whatever...
2) Is the result still OK?  If "yes" then fine.
3) If no, then it's never OK.

Not rocket science.

text:
What is ADHD?
In the past, ADHD was viewed as a deficit or problem. Whilst ADHD can certainly present additional barriers to learning and daily life, it’s not a deficit.
Rather, ADHD is a type of neurodiversity. (2/7)

text: @brucewwenzel @emdyyy__ @EricMGarcia Autistic bodyminds are highly diverse, though, and the scope of that diversity does sometimes include substantial impairments. Neither the social model of disability nor the neurodiversity paradigm, nor anything I've written about either, has ever been intended to deny this fact.

text: To anyone who says stuff like “well, I’m autistic so I can’t be ablest if I’m harassing this autistic person” stop. You are being ableist. You’re so full of self-hate and trauma that you think your neurodiversity is a curse. To you, you feel like the unprivileged one.

text: Or I sometimes think that the ND people who use KF or 4chan are so full of self-hate for themselves that they are masking to the point where they feel ashamed of their neurodiversity. They take it out on those who unmask perhaps because people in their lives force them to mask.

It is acceptance.

It is a movement.

text:
What does saying neurodiversity isn't a "real thing" even mean? I mean, sure - it isn't diagnosis in and of itself.

But... 

Neurodiversity is as real as biodiversity or cultural diversity. It is a concept that encompasses all of the normal variations of human neurology.

4. Lack of embracing neurodiversity.

That messy office doesn't

Not all offices are designed with neurodiversity in mind. And this can be a real setback. 🙅‍♀️

Lighting, sound and unclear signage are examples of the many factors that can cause great discomfort to some.

text:
❤️#This.👇🏼
•#Neurodiversity is neural diversity, conceptually.
•#ND/#Neurodivergent ≠ #NT/#Neurotypical.
•#Neurodiverse = diverse people, but *not* a single person.

•Explaining relevant definitions ≠ #gatekeeping—#grammar & #spelling #policing ND folks oftentimes is.
(1/3) https://t.co/j0aDknKhC0

text:
Think about kids in elementary school every day. They often start their day with a bus ride, which is usually loud and mostly unsupervised (at least here, there is only the driver, who has to focus on — y’know, driving).

#Neurodiversity #Neurodivergent #Writing #Writers #Write

text:
This.

'Neurodiversity' is literally just the concept that all brains are different from each other. It includes the entire human species.

'Neurodivergent' specifies that the brain in question works differently to what is considered 'typical' for humans (ie 'neurotypical'). https://t.co/cOSM60NxTG

Exciting NQP post
Are you looking to:
🟣 work in a Neurodiversity Affirming way?

text: @sandra869pritch @emgntdivergence The concept of neurodiversity understands, among other things, autism, ADHD, dyscalculia, dyslexia and dyspraxia as a natural form of human diversity, which is subject to the same social dynamics as other forms of diversity, and thus opposes a pathological connotation. 1/2

text:
Unsurprisingly a lot of people are upset at the thought that neurodivergence encompasses more than autism and ADHD.

The truth is that their upset is rooted in stigma, ableism, and sanism.

The neurodiversity movement was never meant to exclude people. It's an inclusive movement.

text: This Twitter account is run by me, Liz Bell (hello!), to promote ZIG/ZAG and the concept of #neurodiversity, to amplify the voices of #neurodivergent people, and to challenge ableism and stigma. Sometimes this may involve professional or personal debate and discussion. (8/12)

text: ZIG/ZAG aims to organise existing knowledge about neurodiversity, to find and reveal interesting connections, and to create new conversations with others who are keen to explore their place in the world. That, after all, is what neurodivergent minds do best. (7/12)

text: Much has already been written about #neurodiversity, by scholars, philosophers, and activists of all neurotypes. ZIG/ZAG does not seek to replicate their work, nor to claim greater or keener insight than any other participants in discussions on the topic. (6/12)

text: #Neurodiversity is not about denying the reality of the neurodivergent experience, nor is it about minimising or dismissing the impairments that neurominorities can – and often do – face in an overwhelmingly neurotypical world. (4/12)

text: The idea of ‘celebrating neurodiversity’ is often used to minimise what is effectively a human rights movement, through the adoption of a strengths-focused narrative that replicates all the problematic individualism of a medical, deficit-based model. (3/12)

text: The term #neurodiversity can be divisive. This is partly because the categories into which it is separated are constantly evolving – but also partly because of a widespread lack of understanding about what it actually means. (2/12)

text:
Neurodiversity breaks binaries of neurotypical vs neurodivergent.  There are broad ranges of neural functions which are healthy and normal parts of the human experience.  

Rather than discuss what went wrong, we should find ways to support, depathologize & elevate neurodiversity
tokenized_text: neurodiversity breaks binaries of neurotypical vs neurodivergent . there are broad ranges of neural functions which are healthy and normal parts of the human experience . rather than discuss what went wrong , we should find ways to support , depathologize & elevate neurodiversity

text:
Neurodiversity describes the full spectrum of biological neural functioning and behavior.  

Neurodivergence refers to neural functioning and behavior outside of what is considered typical.  

These terms have cultural specificity as to what is typical and divergent.
tokenized_text: neurodiversity describes the full spectrum of biological neural functioning and behavior . neurodivergence refers to neural functioning and behavior outside of what is considered typical . these terms have cultural specificity as to what is typical and divergent .

text:
@AuDHD_Adult I’m childhood diagnosed, emphatically reject the disability label but not the autism label, and my diagnosis is the reason I:
- didn’t have kids
- didn’t emigrate 
- couldn’t join the military.

Though I support neurodiversity I really wish I didn’t have the official label.

text:
One person cannot be neurodiverse, they would actually be neurotypical or nuerodivergent. 
Neurodiversity is similar to biodiversity, it isn't meant to describe just one person's brain but the wide range of brain possibilities.

text:
@juiicylucy @trainofscones @dustychipura I don't differentiate. As far as I'm concerned, without my ADHD - I just wouldn't be me, so, I just wouldn't be (it's certainly true biologically).
That's also why "person first" language doesn't work for me in relation to neurodiversity.

I can’t stop smiling.

text:
@primatesays @JackVeraldi Agreed! Although rejecting 'suffering' as a descriptor ≠ denying impairment.

I think there's a misconception (which I fully understand) that 'embracing neurodiversity' means erasing our very real struggles in favour of a rainbows-and-unicorns view that 'everyone is special!'

text: I’m not surprised that, with my parents taking me for sight and hearing tests for both these behaviours, I wasn’t assessed for autism- people like me slip under the radar. But surely now we need to be considering how neurodiversity in itself is more like a spectrum.
tokenized_text: i ’ m not surprised that , with my parents taking me for sight and hearing tests for both these behaviours , i wasn ’ t assessed for autism - people like me slip under the radar . but surely now we need to be considering how neurodiversity in itself is more like a spectrum .

text: I really think there needs to be a tidal shift in how we research neurodiversity comorbidity. I say this as someone with ADHD & Dyslexia who recently discovered that not responding to your name and side-eyeing instead of looking directly as a child are both early signs of autism.

text: Theory from a couch psychologist: When cats & dogs wag their tails it's for the same reason. They are highly stimulated. Dogs tend to enjoy this level of excitement, but for a cat it can quickly result in frustration. That's why they need to scratch/bite. #Neurodiversity

text:
PS there are 3 main groups of academics with quals in autism. Generalising: 
a) Behaviourists, who want us to only move/speak in approved ways.
b) The Cure Brigade, who treat us as a medical fault to be fixed without our consent.
c) The Neurodiversity Pioneers. I'm in this group.

text:
Do people with neurodiversity get a pass because we are neurodiverse?  Why would we?

I think there are exceptions (for example Tourettes) that we should consider that a person's words might not represent them.  But a lot of times they do represent us.  It's a judgment call.

text: @JoyceJedlicka Neurodiversity is all that exists in the diversity of human neurotypes including neurotypicals. Neurodiverse refers to a group that has two or more neurotypes represented in it. Neurodivergent is a neurotype that diverges from neurotypical/neuronormative.

text: @momatoes I think part of what makes it tough to navigate use of ‘neurodiversity’ is that sometimes it’s used as a stand-in or justification for a more broadly needed end goal—accommodations—which is a word traditional associated with (but here deliberately divorced from) ‘disability’
tokenized_text: <user> i think part of what makes it tough to navigate use of ‘ neurodiversity ’ is that sometimes it ’ s used as a stand - in or justification for a more broadly needed end goal — accommodations — which is a word traditional associated with ( but here deliberately divorced from ) ‘ disability ’

text: @momatoes My understanding of ‘neurodiversity’ has been as a counterpoint to a medical model—*not* something that needs to be “treated” or “cured”—so one could understandably support accommodations & support for psychosis disorders without considering them part of ‘neurodiversity.’
tokenized_text: <user> my understanding of ‘ neurodiversity ’ has been as a counterpoint to a medical model — not <emphasis> something that needs to be “ treated ” or “ cured ” — so one could understandably support accommodations & support for psychosis disorders without considering them part of ‘ neurodiversity . ’

text:
It's that important to me. Disability rights and issues, neurodiversity, dismantling ableism, calling out abusers, standing up for abuse victims, recognizing all forms of ableism, supporting those who have no support. 

That is what I live for and I can't change it. I accept it.
